review_blob:
Sometimes youve just got to take the wife out for a drink - the good part of this tale of woe, is you get to taste more booze.

This is a perfectly acceptable if not overly sweet fruit beer, that is heavy on the Passion Fruit and Peach.

Easy drinking Golden Ale.

Nothing too complex - fairly well balanced.

Better than Englands performance against Italy at any rate.

Traditional English bitter.

Biscuity (Malted Milk). Thin.

Tried out of nostalgia for a particularly messy afternoons drinking in Manchester (circa 1995 at a guess).

Not as good as I remembered it.

Nice enough golden beer.

Some fruitiness - citrus and peachy.

A good session ale.

Pretty average tasting beer - not what I expect when I plump for an IPA.- no real citrus notes, just an easy drinking session beer.

Suppose the sub 5% alcohol should have tipped me off.

Delicious chocolate coated mule kick.

Probably only one person reading this review will get this...

"Rabbit Gravy"

Finished off an impromptu session with this.

Hunter S Thompson would have stripped to the waist and bare-knuckle fought for a snifter of this fine behemoth of a beer.

Had I imbibed more than a snifter, I would probably have ended up doing the same....

Looks great - Amber, thin white head.

Tastes citrus, light sweetness.

Clarty.

A light beer that looks better than it drinks.

Tasted during a bit of a session, so really didnt stand up to the other beers.

Dont get me wrong, if my local served it, Id happily pop in for a crafty one on my way home from work, but I wouldnt go out of my way for it.

Thick. Hoppy. Strong and fairly tasty.

Claims to be the best beer of its type in the blurb - not entirely convinced.

Gives you wobbly legs if you drink too much though.
beer_name: Bristol Beer Factory UNLIMITED Double IPA

review_blob:
Delicious, in a strong smokey beer kind of way.

On tap at the Sheffield Tap.
One for a beer garden session on a warm Summers day - could quite easily see myself dropping a few of these..

Pours with a tight creamy head.

Barely noticeable caramel aroma.

Bland taste with a soft Oak on the finish,


I love Rum and I love Beer, but I dont like Rummy Beer.

I had to work away from home this week, and that means meals in Beefeater Steakhouses.
Now these places are well known the poor choice of draught ales that they offer.

 Imagine my delight when I spotted this in the bottle fridge (Id resigned myself to Peroni as the best of a bad bunch...)

Delicious, Hoppy, Citrus with a nice level of alcohol.

It may have been the pleasant surprise at these now being stocked, but I ended up having five.

Bottle from B&M.;

Aroma: Fruity (Apple), Caramel, Alcohol
Appearance: Pours amber with a creamy head. Head dissipates quickly. Carbonation in evidence.
Taste: Malty, Spiced Apple, Caramel and Alcohol. 
Palate: Medium body, Sticky and fizzy, with a bitter finish.

Overall: Meh. Strong but ultimately unsatisfying.


Bottle # 2160603

Bottle from Microbrewery outlet.

Aroma: Coffee, Ovaltine, Fruity

Appearance: Very dark brown, creamy head.

Taste: Bitter, Fruity and some hoppyness.

Palate: Light carbonation, thin(ish) with a bitter finish.

Quite an enjoyable drink, with a surprising Fruity/Hoppy combination. Doubt youd want more than the one per session though...

Bottle from Microbrewery Outlet Shop Nantwich.

Aroma: Zesty, Citrus.

Appearance: There is no mention of this beer being bottle conditioned, however it poured very cloudy, with lots of floaters - More of a Weissbier in appearance. Golden Hazy, with a tight creamy head.

Taste: Bitter, slightly Sour (Citrus not rank).

Palate: Light to medium body, very soft carbonation. Clean finish.

A very quaffable beer - one for warm Summer days - i could imagine putting a few of these away in an sunny Beer garden afternoon session.
Shame about the first impressions with the appearance though.

Bottle from B&M.;

My 2nd attempt at this beer - tried it a little more chilled this time.

Aroma: Caramel, Malty

Appearance: Pours dark red brown, tight creamy head. Looks like a Cola Float.

Taste: Sweet, Sweet and a bit more Sweet. And then a touch of "Whisky" on the finish.

Palate: Fizzy and Syrupy

Not one Ill be rushing to drink again.

Bottle from Microbrewery Outlet.

Pours dark brown, almost black with a tight creamy head - almost carbonated with the natural fizz from being bottle conditioned.

Aroma - Dark Chocolate with a light Coffee note. Slight hint of Chilli.

Flavour - Lightly smoked, subtle chilli on the finish.

Palate - Light, almost thin in the mouth.

Quite an enjoyable drink, but I doubt if i could manage more than a pint before it became a little dull.

Bottle from beer outlet at Dagfields, south of Crewe.

Bottle conditioned, that pours slightly cloudy, despite care taken when pouring. Amber in colour, with a thin cream coloured head.

Aroma - Leaf mold (more precisely the rotting vegetation under leaves), dried tobacco.

Flavour - Cheap off-brand sugary Licorice, a sharpness that isnt quite vinegar, but is almost there.

Was it the worst beer ive had recently? No, but its getting close.
